newsitem.title: COTE D'IVOIRE: Ivory Jan cocoa bean exports fall, cumulative up.
newsitem.headline: Ivory Jan cocoa bean exports fall, cumulative up.

text.p: Ivory Coast cocoa bean exports dropped to 137,664 tonnes in January from 166,268 in December, but the cumulative total was up on the 1995/96 season, official shipping data show.
Cumulative exports for the first four months of 1996/97 (Oct-Sept) were 447,406 tonnes, up from 435,215 in the same period of 1995/96 and 403,764 in 1994/95.
Traders said exports in 1995/96, Ivory Coast's record production year, had been slowed by a shipping dispute over freight rates before shipments picked up again in January.
Exports in January 1996/97 were slowed by low world prices and demand, they said.
Figures show that 99,525 tonnes of January 1997 bean exports were shipped from Abidjan with 38,114 tonnes leaving via San Pedro.
In 1995/96, Abidjan handled 110,721 tonnes of January exports with 54,237 tonnes leaving via San Pedro.
Traders said some exporters had stored cocoa rather than shipping in December to earn higher prices expected for March contracts.
Some said they had paid too much for December export contracts through Ivory Coast's electronic export contract auction system which was set up in April 1996.
Warehouse stocks have remained high since December but exporters expect large shipments to leave this month. March cocoa prices hit seven-month highs in New York this week.
Auction rules, which some traders say encourage exporters to overbid to secure export contracts, are under review by donors and the Caistab cocoa marketing body.

Ivory Coast produced 1.2 million tonnes of cocoa in 1995/96. It originally forecast 950,000 tonnes for 1996/97 but Commodities Minister Guy-Alain Gauze said this week no more that 800,000 was available for sale.
Cocoa arrivals were in a 920,000 to 960,000 tonnes range by March 7 (since October 1) with most estimates between 920,000 tonnes and 940,000 tonnes.
Prospects for mid-crop volumes arriving at ports from April onwards are still being assessed by crop analysts.
